summary: The U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland today entered a final judgment in favor of a Maryland man who was sentenced to prison for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Baltimore, Maryland, alleges that on October 1, 2006, Edwin Robles filed a motion to modify child support based on a 2012 change in the federal law that prevents child support arrearages from accruing when a parent is incarcerated.  According to the complaint, Mr. Robles was ordered to pay $430 per month in child support, plus $40 per month toward arrears, by consent order dated February 20, 2015, by wage lien through the SEC.  In a parallel action, the Maryland Attorney General's Office today announced criminal charges against Robles.  On December 5, 2017, the court granted the SEC's request for a temporary restraining order and ordered the Office of Child Support Enforcement (OCSE) to perform an audit to determine the amount of child support owed to the obligor.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC’s complaint, Robles consented to the entry of the final judgment, which permanently enjoins him from violating Section 12-104.1 of the Exchange Act and orders him to pay a civil penalty of $23,154, not $9,890.  Robles also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years, and to be prohibited from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any securities in connection with the issuance of or purchase of any security, including the right to reapply as a matter of law upon his release from prison.   The court also ordered the OCEA to conduct an audit and to determine whether there is sufficient evidence to support the findings of the Commission's investigation.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 5-1038(a)(2)(i)(2) (2007).  The complaint also alleges that, in a parallel proceeding, the SEC improperly issued a cease-and-desist order for Robles to file a motion for a preliminary injunction against future violations of the federal securities laws, and that the court improperly issued an order granting the request for an injunction against further enforcement of the securities laws.  Finally, the complaint alleges that the Court improperly granted the court's order for a delay in issuing an order requiring an accounting of the amount owed to an obligor, which
